summary: Court Wood was a student with pro-Castro sentiments in 1961. He had recently returned from Cuba under the sponsorship of the FAIR PLAY FOR CUBA COMMITTEE. He was of interest to the CIA, specifically Michael Stratton (aka Trial Stratton), who was tasked with maintaining contact with Wood and reporting on his activities. Stratton reported on Wood's involvement with the FAIR PLAY FOR CUBA COMMITTEE and his plans to illegally enter Cuba. Stratton also sought guidance on his relationship with Wood and his father.
significance: Court Wood's significance in the JFK context lies in his association with the FAIR PLAY FOR CUBA COMMITTEE and his pro-Castro sentiments during a period of heightened tensions between the US and Cuba. The CIA's interest in monitoring his activities suggests a concern about potential connections between pro-Castro groups and individuals and any threats to national security. The documents indicate that the CIA was actively gathering intelligence on individuals involved with the FAIR PLAY FOR CUBA COMMITTEE.
